Grok-3: Best Model on the Planet?

Well, Maybe Not Quite

Kenji

AI Unscripted

2

So, I’ve been testing out Grok-3, the latest AI model that’s been making waves. I know — I’m a bit late to the party. It feels like everyone and their GPU has already shared their hot take. But I wanted to give it a proper shot, integrate it into my daily workflow, and see if it actually lives up to the hype.

Here’s my take after a week of coding and planning with it — what works, what doesn’t.

First, Why All the Hype?

Grok-3 isn’t just another AI model — it’s Elon Musk’s xAI stepping up in the AI race, and it’s got people talking. It topped the LM Arena leaderboards, becoming the first model to break the 1,400 score mark. With a massive 200,000 Nvidia H100 GPU setup, it’s challenging AI giants like OpenAI, Google, and DeepSeek.

The mission behind Grok? To be a “maximally truthful” AI, drawing inspiration from The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy. Sounds fun, but the real question is: Does that make it useful? That’s what I set out to explore.

Coding with Grok-3: My Debugging Hero

First stop: coding. I’ve been testing Grok-3’s “thinking model” for a week, and honestly? It’s solid.

I had a tricky debugging issue — even Sonnet 3.5 in Cursor struggled with it. So, I threw my notes and the problem at Grok-3, and it actually helped me solve it—a definite win.

But it’s not perfect. Here’s where it falls short:

Still, it’s a solid choice for debugging and problem-solving — especially when you need a different perspective.

Planning with Grok-3: Useful But Overcomplicated

Next, I tested Grok-3 for project planning. I asked it to outline features, estimate costs, and organize resources for an upcoming project.

It delivered… sort of.

The output was thorough — maybe too thorough for me. It piled on so much detail that it made things more complex than necessary. Maybe I just haven’t figured out the best way to prompt it for planning, but I found myself going back to O3, which gave me simpler, more actionable insights.

Grok-3 was useful, but a bit much.

Grok-3’s Secret Sauce: What’s Under the Hood?

Beyond my own experience, Grok-3 brings some serious hardware and new capabilities to the table. Here’s what sets it apart:

Serious Compute Power: Trained using 200,000 Nvidia H100 GPUs, making it one of the most resource-intensive models ever built.

Advanced Processing Modes: It offers three distinct settings —

Benchmark Performance: Outperformed models like Gemini 2 Pro, DeepSeek-V3, and Claude 3.5 Sonnet in math, science, and coding evaluations.

So, Where Does It Fit?

After using it for coding and planning, I’d place Grok-3 somewhere between DeepSeek-R1 and O3.

What’s Next?

I’m not done with Grok-3 yet. I’ll keep using it — especially if Cursor integration happens soon. That would make it way more convenient.

Also, voice mode is coming soon, and I’m really curious to see if it adds some personality.
